I think we should stick to not having this in test-requirements. We can test that the new routine finds what we expect in a test module that we hand to it (the code even takes the libvirt module as an argument). It also means if libvirt adds a new object our test will have to change, at which time we'll have to make a hard version bump here, and then local testing without that version won't be possible.

I'm totally comfortable with this being validated with a unit-y test that passes in a fake module and this isn't a good reason to bring back the dep, IMHO.

Yeah, we purged it in favour of using fakelibvirt for all unit testing to avoid the native dep.

I seem to remember we had libvirt-python in test-requirements many years ago but removed it because of that, or some issues with the gate, or libvirt-python in pypi, I can't remember off the top of my head. initscripts-config/files/sysctl.conf.message:
This was originally added by Chris under the following commit:

CGTS-457: adjust local port range to protect libvirt  Libvirt uses the port range 49152-49215 for live migrations. Unfortunately it appears to be using them in an unsafe manner and if something else is already using the port it doesn't recover gracefully. This causes the live migration to fail.  As a workaround, this commit bumps up the bottom of the ephemeral port range to just higher than the range used by libvirt.

Just want to confirm that this issue no longer exists?
Good question. The commit message only notes the removal of the tcp_tw_reuse parameter. Why is this setting being removed as well? How does this relate to message loss?

Hi, Penny:
   The commit comment mentioned this change "remove customizing ephemeral port range". in this commit, it will use default ephemeral port range of centos.

The commit message does mention that this is being removed to restore the expanded ephemeral port range.  This change is required to help avoid ephemeral port exhaustion since the tcp_tw_reuse flag is being turned off.

This was originally added by Joseph under the following commit:

US75532: enable tcp_tw_reuse  This commit enables 

tcp_tw_reuse so that sockets in TIMED_WAIT state can be reused. This is necessary because of the high number of calls that are made through the vswitch API for the providernet connectivity feature. Because the vswitch API makes a call to curl for each request, this results in the system frequently running out of available TCP ports when a connectivity audit is run.

Just want to confirm that this issue no longer exists?

Hi, Bart
    I have discussed with Matt, the issue should be not existing in current stx. so it is ok to use default tcp_tw_reuse (0)

ceph-osd/values.yaml.message:
we should give a recommendation which one to use. Also for bluestore we don't have to pass journal explicitly

If there is only a small amount of fast storage available (e.g., less than a gigabyte), we recommend using it as a WAL device. If there is more, provisioning a DB device makes more sense. The BlueStore journal will always be placed on the fastest device available, so using a DB device will provide the same benefit that the WAL device would while also allowing additional metadata to be stored there (if it will fix).

The default configuration uses FileStore as it always has. This can be overridden if BlueStore is desired. I disagree that we should give a recommendation. Hardware and other factors determine which is best suited for the deployment. Which would we recommend?

While BlueStore doesn't need a journal specified, the logic for the ceph-osd deployment expects the value to exist. It should be left blank for BlueStore deployments as the block.db and block.wal locations are blank by default for FileStore deployment. This can be considered first-step solution that can be improved upon later. This is intended to be a quick solution to get BlueStore support.
change to block_db: instead of location please
perhaps we should give an example for bluestore with type: bluestore

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is the remaining trigger for running 'refresh_helm_repo_information()' in _upload_helm_charts() sufficient? Previously, was being performed on sysinv-conductor init.

It appears that running helm_repo_update() as part of application-upload also has the effect of blocking sysinv-conductor operations (i.e. may see other rpc timeouts if any pending during this operation).

As per Bob Church: "This would be still be called as part of kube_app.py/ _upload_helm_charts () to ensure that as part of the application-upload we have an up-to-date view of the StarlingX helm repos. We would leave it as an exercise for the user to run ‘helm repo update’ for ensuring any external repos information is synced outside of the application-uploads."

That's why we are moving it to agent. Conductor is a single threaded application and we cannot allow it to stuck for 2 minutes. There are bunch of agents, so let one f them stuck and wait for this helm repo refresh.

neutron/db/extraroute_db.py.message: I guess if {} is passed we can't return early because the API is returning the router?

Similar question here - if the 'add' didn't actually add a new route do we still need to update the router?  Corner case I know but there's going to be an update sent to the l3-agent's that could be avoided.

Same questions for delete.

I understand you want to optimize the "empty update" because that can be replaced with a "get", so we don't trigger the deeper side effects (e.g. I/O to the agents), right?

This optimization makes sense. But I think this should be done in update_router(). Because there a single change will optimize all calls to update_router(). Why would we want to optimize at all places where we call update_router() instead of doing it once in update_router() itself? Especially that update_router() already contains a get_router() so there's no extra db cost there to do this.

Yes, just trying to avoid work.

Looking at update_router/_update_router_db, it does handle the [] case by not doing a DB update, but will still emit a event, which I guess is OK.

I guess this case of 'routes' being the same before/after is a subset of that - nothing has changed, but we do a DB update anyways.  The router_update code doesn't attempt to handle that, and it doesn't look trivial to change it.

In the end it's an edge case, and the user made the API call so knows what they're doing....

If there are two entries with same destination and different nexthops, the one entry will be overridden by the other.
Don't we consider (dest, nexthop) pair as unique entry?
Good catch. I don't what I had been thinking when I fixed this problem in _add_extra_routes() but did not fix it here.

for me this new method isn't atomic at all. Imagine that You have 2 neutron-servers, now You are doing two calls to add some routes to router. First request is going to first neutron-server where You have old=[] and second goes to second neutron-server where You also have old=[]. Now each of them adds one new extraroute and saves it in db. Finally only one of those 2 extraroutes will be added.

Am I missing something here?
Ok, You're totally right. It's fine. Sorry for the noise.
We should be in a DB transaction. Am I completely misunderstanding the db_api.CONTEXT_WRITER context manager?

The use case that's actually affected is when multiple clients claim their need for the exact same route (and the route should be there from the first add until all of them removed/released it) - that's the one we discussed at the beginning of this cycle and said we don't want to support it. So I'm baffled.

There's no compare and swap here - that's intentional. But the add and remove diffs/requests (multiple routes in each diff) sent by multiple clients should be applied serially because of the DB transactions. The order of the diffs is not guaranteed by anything, but as long as multiple clients don't try to add/remove the *exact same* route what kind of use case would be broken by that?

neutron/tests/unit/db/test_extraroute_db.message: assertSetEqual might be used. If so, the failure message would be a bit more human-friendly.
Why do we need to convert frozenset into set?

We don't convert. It's a set of frozensets. The inner set has to be frozen otherwise it's not hashable, so it cannot be put in the outer set.

The inner set is needed so we can ignore the dict order of a single route (dst-nexthop or nexthop-dst).
The outer set is needed so we can ignore the order of routes.
Ah.. I see. Thanks for the explanation. I seemed to be confused.

From the readability, it is better to introduce "old" and "add" variables.

  old = [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"}]
  add = []
  self._plugin._add_extra_routes(old, add)

or

  self._plugin._add_extra_routes(
    old=[{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"}],
    add=[])

Same comment for the remove_route test below.

I think a test for normal removal is missing. Special cases are covered.

  self.assertEqual(
      [],
      self._plugin._remove_extra_routes(
          [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"}],
          [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"}],
      ),
  )

and/or

  self.assertEqual(
      [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"}],
      self._plugin._remove_extra_routes(
          [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"},
            {"destination": "10.0.20.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.11"}],
          [{"destination": "10.0.20.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.11"}],
      ),
  )

The following test is worth added: two entries with same destination and different nexthops.

  old = [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"},
         {"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.11"}]
  remove = [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"}]

I expect the return value would be:

  [{"destination": "10.0.10.0/24", "nexthop": "10.0.0.10"}]

I generally understand what the strategy needs to do, that is, to migrate some nodes' virtual machines to other nodes as much as possible.
I agree we need this strategy.
However, I feel that there is a description of a step missing here, that is, how to let some nodes' virtual machines migrate, and what are the rules.
Is this why the new planner is needed? to identify migrations that failed previously.

No. The default planner can't create actions with correct order, so we need a new planner to do it. For example, if there are 3 actions in solution.actions:[change_nova_sevice(disabled),migrate,change_nova_service(enabled)], the default planner will create actions: [change_nova_service(disabled), change_nova_service(enabled),migrate], That's not what we want.

I think we're good:

Old destination (numa_live_migration can only be False, RPC has to be pinned, but I've included all possibilities for completeness):

  numa_live_migration | do_cleanup | RPC pinned | result

    False                   True        Yes        rlmad() called with do_cleanup stripped
                                                   out by rpcapi. This is fine as the old
                                                   rlmad() doesn't know about do_cleanup
                                                   anyways, so it just cleans up.
    False                   True        No         NA
    False                   False       Yes        rlmad() not called.
                                                   Same as pre-NUMA-LM.
    False                   False       No         NA
    True                    True        Yes        NA
    True                    True        No         NA
    True                    False       Yes        NA
    True                    False       No         NA

New destination:

    False                   True        Yes        rlmad() called with do_cleanup stripped
                                                   out by rpcapi, the True default kicks
                                                   in and _do_rlmad() is called. This is
                                                   equivalent to the old behaviour of
                                                   calling rlmad() if do_cleanup is True.
    False                   True        No         rlmad() called with do_cleanup=True
                                                   _do_rlmad() is called. This is
                                                   equivalent to the old behaviour of
                                                   calling rlmad() if do_cleanup is True.
    False                   False       Yes        rlmad() not called.
                                                   Same as pre-NUMA-LM.
    False                   False       No         rlmad() not called.
                                                   Same as pre-NUMA-LM.
    True                    True        Yes        rlmad() called with do_cleanup stripped
                                                   out by rpcapi, the True default kicks
                                                   in and _do_rlmad() is called. This is
                                                   equivalent to the old behaviour of
                                                   calling rlmad() if do_cleanup is True.
    True                    True        No         rlmad() called with do_cleanup=True.
                                                   _do_rlmad() is called, same as
                                                   pre-NUMA-LM.
    True                    False       Yes        rlmad() called with do_cleanup stripped
                                                   out by rpcapi. The True default kicks
                                                   in, and we do cleanup when we
                                                   shouldn't. This is a problem.
    True                    False       No         rlmad() called with do_cleanup=False.
                                                   _do_rlmad() is not called. Same as
                                                   pre-NUMA-LM.

Discussed with Dan & Matt to clarify. I think this means:
- Create a new OVO base class, e.g. ResourceMetadata, and register it (decorate with @obj_base.NovaObjectRegistry.register)
- Make this (Resource.metadata) an ObjectField('ResourceMetadata', nullable=True)
- Make LibvirtPMEMDevice a subclass of ResourceMetadata (in the patch where it's introduced).
- Use obj rather than json (de)serialization on the Resource.metadata field as needed.
- Profit.

Isn't someone going to try to also set trait:FOO=forbidden in a partially-overlapping aggregate to make sure that only part of their windows machines get some instances?

Point being, I'd prefer to query out the aggregates by the presence of a key of "trait:FOO". That should not only yield fewer things for us to process below, but also let us log, warn, or fail if they try to do complex set math that we don't support. Could we just grab all the required traits, construct the list of keys and pass them to an aggregate command as an IN query? For large numbers of aggregates with any required traits, this is going to process them all. Further, if you have an aggregate with five special boxes among ten thousand regular ones, we have to do this processing for every instance regardless of special-ness.

I understand the desire to make this magically look the same as host traits, but it seems like doing that makes it fairly expensive. I've thought of a couple ways to make this more efficient, but none I want to admit to, but I'll keep pondering.

> Isn't someone going to try to also set trait:FOO=forbidden in a
 > partially-overlapping aggregate to make sure that only part of
 > their windows machines get some instances?

As currently designed & written, that'll be ignored. Easiest thing is to simply document that that's not supported.

(If we ever did want to support something like that - though I'm not sure what it would mean - it wouldn't be a big deal to ask for aggregates with metadata value 'required' or 'forbidden'.)

(Also, if you wanted to satisfy a use case like that, wouldn't you just do it by putting an *additional* CUSTOM_SNOWFLAKE trait on your overlapping aggregate and requiring that trait on your FOO+SNOWFLAKE instances?)

 > Point being, I'd prefer to query out the aggregates by the presence
 > of a key of "trait:FOO".

That only works if you know the full set of traits you could possibly be filtering on. Unfortunately, that's all of them (237 standard at 0.14.0, plus whatever custom ones you've added).

It is explicitly *not* sufficient to ask for all the aggregates that have a key IN "trait:%s" % t for t in (flavor_traits + image_traits), because not all flavor+image traits (in fact very very few of them) are going to be required on aggregates.

How many aggregates are going to have metadata properties with value 'required' anyway? Off the cuff, I'm guessing this is way more efficient than `key IN ("trait:%s" % t for t in $list_of_237_plus_traits)"` or even `key LIKE "trait:%"`.

 > For large numbers of
 > aggregates with any required traits

How many is that? Does CERN really have tens of thousands of aggregates? Do we suspect that even as many as ten of them will have required traits?

But

This was all considered in the spec review. I believe we said we'd do it the dumb way first; and if it turns out to be a problem for performance, we would find a way to save the aggregate required traits somewhere more quickly accessible.

Added new method get_non_matching_by_metadata_keys() [1] which will return aggregates that are not matching with metadata.

keystone/common/policies/access_rule.py.message: These access rules are not scoped to domains?

I think not. For the moment, you can only create application credentials for projects, so project members should be able to see their application credentials, and I think system readers should be able to see users' access rules but I can't really think of a reason domain readers should need to. I'm open to discuss it though.
Yes, I think domain readers should not need to see the application credentials but domain admin should be able to?

I think the reader role should be able to do any GET action so I don't think we should distinguish between reader and admin for get_access_rule here.

We had a related discussion about domain admins and application credentials yesterday: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-keystone/%23openstack-keystone.2019-07-16.log.html#t2019-07-16T17:01:50

I think the gist is that while domain admins can manage users themselves, we don't need them to manage things that the users own, i.e. application credentials, trusts, or access rules.

When we add support for scoping an application credential to a domain, we'll have to add 'domain' to the scope type here, but we'll still have to ensure that users can only manage their own app creds and not another user's.

Access rules are indirectly project specific, right? You can't create them directly with the API but only by creating an application credential (with access rules as an argument) and since app creds require projects each set of access rules are indirectly associated to a project, yeah?

I'm thinking about cases where we have many duplicate access rules in the backed. Each would be specific to an application credential. I'm wondering if in the future we going to be able to optimize that case?

Creating access rules are indirectly project specific, yes. My thinking here was that a system admin should be able to manage them and clean them up, since they aren't automatically deleted when an app cred is deleted. An access rule record isn't specific to a particular app cred, they are only specific to a user, so they won't be duplicated except when different users create the same ones.

So I'm not following all the discussion for this feature, apologize if I asked something people already discussed.

It's a valid concern, and while we have sort of talked about this before, it's worth going over again.

Essentially, the NUMA objects are an imcomplete model: they are *almost* enough for the source to update the XML, but not quite. For example, emulator threads get placed on CONF.compute.cpu_shared_set if the emulator threads policy is `share`. Only the destination host knows what its cpu_shared_set is, and that information only exists as a config option.

I've left a TODOO to this effect in another patch [1]. It'd be good to improve this, but maybe let's start with a baseline that's easier to implement by re-using as much existing code as possible?

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634828/24/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py@6752

> * reusing existed libvifg config generation code

Wouldn't that be the main advantage of doing the config generation on the dest? Looking at _get_guest_numa_config(), there's a whole bunch of places where it depends on the host it's running on:

[1] calls [2], and just in _get_host_numa_topology() there's [3], [4], [5], [6] and [7] that are dest-specific.

I'm not saying we need all of those for live migration, so we could conceivably have the dest send its host topology, its vcpu_pin_set, and anything else that might be necessary, to the source, and the source can update the XML from that.

However, it's just so much safer to use the existing _get_guest_numa_config() on the dest by giving it what it needs to know about the instance.

The alternative would be to reproduce parts of the logic of _get_guest_numa_config() on the source with information sent from the dest, but that would be new fragile code.

Yes, actually I mean we put the dest host numa obj and dest host cpu shared set and etc all we need in the NUMAMigrateData obj.

Then we use the libvirt config building code of source node to generate the XML with those dest host info.

Pros:
  * avoid to hack xml
  * reusing existed libvifg config generation code
  * reusing existed obj, avoid to add new obj
Cons:
  * more data transfer between dest and src host
  * If the source host and dest host are running in different version, they may have different way to build libvirt config. Then the src node may build a wrong libvirt config for dest node, but I don't think it will happy, since libvirt probably need same libvirt config on two nodes to make the LM successful.

tl;dr +1

note that today when using vcpu_pin_set for non numa instances the operator is expected to use host aggreates to group host with the same vcpu_pin_set to ensure that you dont need to regenerate teh xml on live migration.

including this allows use to remove that restriction by updating the xml for non numa guest.

using vcpu_pin_set for reserving cpu for host use has several advandages the primary one being the ability to partition which cpus are reserved for the host which allows you to configure systemd or other services to run on just those cores.

since this can vary per host we in principal need to update the cpu set on migration, in practice by requiring operators to set the same value across all host we have avoided that.

before this change set floating instance would not be updated on migration. if the source set was contined cpu not on the dest node libvirt would reject the migration

if libvirt allowed the migration because all cpus were present on the dest then the vm would float over incorrect cpus until it was hard rebooted at which point it will use the correct cores. 


this will remove the need for operators to understand this bit of tribal knowadge as it was pointed out that this behavior is not commonly known or documented upstream.

the <vcpu cpuset=X-Y> is a shorthand for the <vcpupin .. > form in the cputune ellement. 

e.g.
<vcpu placement='static' cpuset="1-4,^3,6" current="2">2</vcpu>

is the same as 

<cputune>
    <vcpupin vcpu="0" cpuset="1-4,^3,6"/>
    <vcpupin vcpu="1" cpuset="1-4,^3,6"/>
</cputune>



both get translated to the same  cgroups.

<vcpu placement='static' cpuset="1-4,^3,6" current="2">2</vcpu>

is the more potable form however it does not allow you to pin indivgual guest cpus to spefic host cpus. that mapping is left to the kernel.

<vcpu placement='static' cpuset="1-4,^3,6" current="2">2</vcpu>

will work for kvm, qemu xen lxc and more.

<vcpupin vcpu="0" cpuset="1-4,^3,6"/>

required the hyperviors to support per core pinning with does not work with qemu and the singel tread tcg backend but does work with qemu and the multi thread tcg backed mttcg, kvm and xen.

we use the most generic form when the guest does not have a numa toplogy to allow it to work with the majority fo libvir  t backends.

this is for the realtime cpus right?
a comment for this would be useful.

It seems like you've said contradicting things, but I'll answer both:

- We need key_prefix because we're trying to identify metadata entries *with that `key_prefix`*, that are *not in the list of `keys`*.

While thinking about how to handle this like _reschedule_resize_or_reraise where we don't reschedule, I'm thinking it would be good to have a functional test that asserts the behavior we expect, which is that the allocations are reverted and whatever other error handling happens normally - like recording a fault and sending a notification. That's easier tested "externally" from a functional test and then the runtime code can be tweaked however we want, e.g. test-driven development.

I have a couple of ideas for alternative ideas to still call _reschedule_resize_or_reraise for the BuildAbortException case but they are kind of icky.

When rescheduled == False in _reschedule_resize_or_reraise we don't send notifications or record fault directly. That call will log 'Retry info not present,...' and then re-raise the exception. So whatever error handling happens for an existing non-reschedule case, will happen for the new BuildAbortException case as well.

I created a functional test that injects the BuildAbortException and asserted that:

* instance is in ERROR, having allocation from the source host.
* migration allocation is deleted
* instance action event is recorded with an Error status.
* notifications are sent

This is racy I think. We're waiting for the server status to go to ERROR which happens here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/7a18209a81539217a95ab7daad6bc67002768950/nova/compute/manager.py#L4476

And we're waiting for the migration status to go to error which happens here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/7a18209a81539217a95ab7daad6bc67002768950/nova/compute/manager.py#L4478

But you're expecting the fault to be set which happens later here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/7a18209a81539217a95ab7daad6bc67002768950/nova/compute/manager.py#L4454

So what you should probably do is also wait for the task_state to be None above since that happens after the fault is recorded:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/7a18209a81539217a95ab7daad6bc67002768950/nova/compute/manager.py#L4452

Know how I know about this kind of race? Because I've hit the same thing before in functional tests I've written for this same kind of resize code. :)

manila/api/v1/shares.py.message:
If an AZ is not specified, shouldn't you allow the scheduler to find an AZ for the share, and than fail if the share network does not support the given AZ?

For example:

My share network has two subnets, one in AZ-a and one in AZ-b; I do not specify an AZ while creating the share - I expect the share to be created in either AZ, as determined by the scheduler with the help of the share type I'm using - but, because of this check, my share creation will fail right here, forcing me to use an AZ - this breaks backwards compatibility

I think you should still perform a check if an AZ is specified and share network does not have a subnet in the AZ and lacks a default subnet... but if the AZ isn't specified, don't fail here, perform the check in the scheduler or share manager.

Hi Goutham, I think you're right. This is a scenario that we aren't considering here. The share can be scheduled to a host that belong to AZ-a or AZ-b, if a subnet for this share-network exists and no AZ was specified. 
Now, we also need to change how the scheduler selects compatible hosts, when the share-network doesn't have a default subnet and no AZ was specified by the user. In this scenario, we need to filter hosts from AZ's that doesn't have an associated subnet.
Thanks for pointing that out.

Update: No changes in the scheduler will be needed if in share api we:
1. Check if a share-network-id was provided and if this share-network has a default/fallback subnet. 
 1.1 SN has a default subnet: nothing changes, the scheduler will select a host in the way it does today.
 1.2 SN doesn't have a default subnet: request spec needs to be updated to have a list of AZs that contains subnets for the requested share-network.
   1.2.1 If the share-type already provide a list of AZs, remove the elements that don't have a assigned subnet and fails if the list becomes empty.
   1.2.2 If the list of AZs is empty, provide a list with all AZ's that contains a subnet and fails if the list ends up with no elements.
   1.2.3 Provide a list of AZs within the request spec to the scheduler choose the better host to place the share.

The idea behind this approach is that the user will not be able to disable this filtering (like a scheduler filter), avoiding an unexpected behavior, since a subnet is mandatory on DHSS=True.
If we let this check to occur only in the share-manager, the scheduler may choose an invalid host to place the share when other valid hosts may exists.
Goutham, let me know if this approach is a valid implementation. Thanks again.

This is being done only for mysql because in other database engine (postgresql) it failed. Some things that motivated me to do it in this way:

- Postgresql didn't show any error during the constraint deletion.
- I surely could do the same for other engine like postgresql, but during some investigations I've realized that postgresql does not respect the name I give to the constraint and when I tried to delete the constraint with this specific name, it fails. manila/tests/api/v2/test_share_networks..message:
I didn't found tests that covers the following scenarios:
 - Delete a share-network that contains 2 or more subnets
 - Share network update with params neutron_net_id and neutron_subnet_id.

Regarding the test to delete share networks with more than one subnet, I have added it but forgot to mock some method calls and these calls are implemented to raise HTTPConflict. I've fixed this test and now it should cover this part of the code.
Regarding the update test you mentioned, I think we should discuss more about this specific case since now both fields no longer belong to share networks and as designed in the specs, the subnets weren't designed to have update operations. I see some ways to work around it:
1. Stop making possible to update this fields from a specific share network. Make the update be possible only when handling with the share network name or description since one or more subnet can have the same neutron [sub]net id.
2. Update these fields for all the subnets that contains the referred neutron [sub]net id (it could cause some problems and update subnets that the user don't want to update).
3. Try to update the fields in the default subnet. If there is only one subnet with the availability zone set to None, the update will work be performed in the default. In case the user contains only one subnet and it contains an availability zone, we also try to update. Otherwise, if there is more than one subnet and it does not contain a subnet with the availability zone set to None, raise an error. IMO, the main problem of this option is the complexity to explain to the user and is definitely not good in terms of usability.
Both 2 and 3 approaches I've mentioned can lead the user to commit mistakes.
It's missing a test where you pass a valid az.

In OVN driver we validate if actually algorithm is supported by driver or not:

We do it during pool_create and pool_update.

So if we're going to move the name from ROUND_RODIN to SOURCE_IP_PORT in provider driver we need to also update already created pools. Why?
Potentially customer could create another pool and will be forced to use SOURCE_IP_PORT. In the list there could be pools with SOURCE_IP_PORT and with ROUND_ROBIN, but in fact we would support only SOURCE_IP_PORT. That's confusing :(

For me better would be to do this name change in the DB during upgrade and leave proper release note that actually algorithm used in OVN is not ROUND_ROBIN at all and we need to change the name of it.

This is very clever and workaround-y, but I definitely wouldn't encourage anyone to write more code like this in the future. I totally get why this is worthwhile for making this backportable, but I do hate to see it live around and provide an example that someone else might copy. I almost wonder if we should put this into a utility method somewhere so that we can (a) not replicate the code itself anywhere else and (b) put lots of warnings above it about when the technique should/can be used and what the downsides are. You've got comments above, which is good, but I can see someone finding this and just lifting the contents elsewhere.

Okay, so I was confused about your intentions here, and I assume Artom was as well. I read this as being defensive about code that called this where access to the API DB was in question (i.e. if they were running multiple cells without api db access as recommended). I see now (and after talking to you) that this is purely an API-level thing and not an upcall. However, I think the overly graceful handling of no api db configuration is why we were both confused. I don't expect we'd even be able to get this far if we had no api db (we couldn't even look up the instance this method is being called for). If we did, there would be a lot of error-level tracebacks being logged, so gently logging at info level that "your entire deployment is configured in a way that can't possibly work" seems a tad out of place.

So, if you're going to catch it and log, I'd say do so at error and then re-raise the exception like all the other API code would.

The other thing you referenced is for code that could legit be called from either api or cell level services and *needs* to be graceful about not requiring api db access. This is wholly different, IMHO.

doc/source/afs.rst.message:
perhaps we should suggest the full salvage as described in [1]

 bos salvage -server afs02.dfw.openstack.org -partition a -showlog -orphans attach -forceDAFS



[1] https://lists.openafs.org/pipermail/openafs-devel/2018-May/020493.html

Unfortunately, that command is unsafe with a dafs fileserver because the vice partition cannot be entirely detached from the fileserver. The safe operation is to bos salvage -server -volume -orphans attach -forceDAFS However, you must still check for volume ids (not names) that are reported by "vos listvol -server " but are unknown to the vl service "vos examine -volid ". Those volumes are clones which the salvager will not delete. Such volume clones must be removed using "vos zap -server -partition

-volid "
Maybe mention vos unlock as the command to specifically remedy locks?

Our fileserver crashed. This prevented `vol examine $volume` from functioning for volumes hosted on that particular fileserver. However the db servers (which I'm guessing are our vol servers) did not crash. This meant that vos listvldb showed locked volumes for volumes that had ongoing vos releases at the time of the crash. These then timed out authentication and became stale.

My suggestion here is to check vos listvdlb after this incident to look for any stale locks as pausing updates and volume release cron jobs means we have no ongoing releases so nothing should be locked.

Any lock that remains at that point should be removed.

VL servers are not the same a VOL servers.   The FILE, VOL, and SALVAGE services are co-dependent processes that execute as part of the same "bnode" launched by the bosserver.

The VL servers run on separate hosts in the openstack.org cell.

Volume transactions will not survive a volserver restart; they certainly will not survive a machine crash.

Volume forwards that involve a volserver terminating unexpectedly might require manual termination of the transaction(s) on the other volserver involved in the volume forward.

  vos status
  vos endtrans

What kind of crash are we documenting recovery of?

Looking at the logs @ http://paste.openstack.org/show/774655/ i'm not 100% sure it was a straight case of couldn't do incremental ... it doesn't have the same "Deleting extant RO_DONTUSE site on afs02.dfw.openstack.org... done" that usually proceeds that.  we did look at the timing of the reboots and this failure in #openstack-infra relating to this at the time
Can this run with the fileserver process running?

Hmm, could we race here? The migration allocations are dropped here right?

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f4ca3e70852c0a7ed7904a9f2d7177c9118d3d1c/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L449

or maybe they are dropped on the compute first:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f4ca3e70852c0a7ed7904a9f2d7177c9118d3d1c/nova/compute/manager.py#L4505

and above we're waiting for the migration status to be 'error' which happens here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f4ca3e70852c0a7ed7904a9f2d7177c9118d3d1c/nova/conductor/tasks/migrate.py#L437

or maybe here in the compute:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f4ca3e70852c0a7ed7904a9f2d7177c9118d3d1c/nova/compute/manager.py#L4492

If the migration is set to error status in the compute then we should be OK because compute reverts the allocations before we hit errors_out_migration_ctxt.
The migration allocation dropped on the compute as well as erroring out the migration. But the error out happens after the allocation is deleted so we are not racing here.
